newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS - Coffee prices take another hit.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Coffee prices take another hit.

text.p: This week's headlong fall in coffee prices continued on Friday as speculators tried to salvage some of their fast diminishing profits.

Among other commodities palladium remained volatile due to a desperate shortage of the metal, several base metals turned higher after being a target of the bears for most of the week, and weather concerns boosted wheat prices.
On the London robusta coffee futures market the July position lost another $80 a tonne, and its day's low of $1,815 showed a 32 percent retracement from last week's 20 months high of $2,670.
"There was nothing new today but once momentum builds in these markets they don't change direction easily," an analyst said.

Traders said this week's fall was a combination of the dizzy rise being overdone, Colombia stepping-up exports and claiming it was finding consumer resistance to high prices, and lack of any signs so far of a damaging frost in the peak June/July winter months in Brazil.

In Europe, palladium reached $240 an ounce, its highest price since 1980, as traders indicated it could be early July before resumed Russian exports, after a six-month absence, began to reach export markets.

The lack of palladium shipments by the world's number one exporter of the metal which is a vital component of auto-catalysts, used to clean up exhaust fumes, has seen the price double since the start of the year.
A big investment fund is holding 1.5 million ounce of pallaidum and this has exacerbated the market shortage quite considerably as world supply is only around five million ounces a year.
Fund involvement was also evident on the London Metal Exchange where a position was believed to have been built up in the tin market which could cause some tightness in supplies during July.
This has seen players with sales commitments rushing to cover their positions and has pushed the price up by around $200 a tonne during the week to $5,700.
Nickel also ended the week on a firm note as neither company or unions involved in the strike at the west's number one nickel producer, Canada's Inco, showed any sign of resuming pay talks.
The possibility that a prolonged strike could see Inco dip into the London Metal Exchange 50,000 tonnes stocpile of the metal helped boost prices above the $7,300 a tonne level, $60 up on the day.
The LMEs flagship copper contract continued its slow recovery from an early-week sell-off to end at $2,487, nearly $30 above the week's low but still short of the $2,500 traded on Monday.
Heavy rains in the wheat growing areas of Texas were delaying the harvest and this pushed Chicago Board of trade prices up by some five cents a bushel.
